p: The most striking result here is the stability of public beliefs about anthropogenic climate change. That holds across different surveys ( Fig 1A) and over a five-year time span ( Fig 2A), although not across places ( Fig 1B). General stability is anchored by wide, persistent political divisions ( Fig 2B). Effects from individual age, gender, education and political party manifest as similar odds ratios on many different surveys ( Table 2). Very similar educationÃ— party interaction effects occur in most of these surveys as well. In social research, interaction effects in multivariate models frequently prove to be sample-specific, so the degree of replication seen in Fig 3 is extraordinary.
